TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed FormMethod extends System.Enum

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Web.Mobile.dll assembly has been deprecated and should no longer be used. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=157231.")

Docs.summary: Specifies the type of submission for a form as a GET or POST request. This class cannot be inherited. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.FormMethod> enumeration represents how you will submit a form. A GET request, when the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Method%2A> property of the form is set to `Get`, is limited in the amount of data it can post. Some types of postbacks might fail when using a GET request. The advantage of using a GET request is that all the parameters are specified as part of the URL, and you can cache or save the URL.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Web.UI.MobileControls.FormMethod Get = int32(0)

Docs.summary: Uses a GET request to submit a form. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Web.UI.MobileControls.FormMethod Post = int32(1)

Docs.summary: Uses a POST request to submit a form. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
